title: 113_hr4496
content: The Act is titled the "Covering People With Pre-Existing Conditions Act of 2014" and establishes universal access programs to improve high-risk pools and reinsurance markets for individuals with pre-existing conditions. Each State must operate a qualified State reinsurance program or a qualifying State high-risk pool by January 1, 2015, funded by State premium assessments. States without a qualified high-risk pool must establish one to comply with the Act. States without a qualified high-risk pool must establish a qualified State reinsurance program to comply with the Act. States already operating a high-risk pool as of the enactment date will not be treated as a qualified high-risk pool as of January 1, 2015. States without a qualified high-risk pool must establish a qualified State reinsurance program to comply with the Act. If a high-risk pool is in strong fiscal health, as determined by NAIC standards and approved by the State Insurance Commissioner, it can transition to a qualified State reinsurance program using premium assessment funds. A qualified State reinsurance program is defined as a program operated by a State that provides reinsurance for health insurance coverage in the small group market. It can operate on a prospective or retrospective basis and protect health insurance issuers against annual aggregate spending of enrollees and catastrophic costs. A qualified State reinsurance program provides protection for health insurance issuers against enrollees' annual spending and catastrophic costs. A qualifying State high risk pool must offer two coverage options, including a high deductible health plan with a health savings account, stable funding, and no waiting lists for eligible residents seeking coverage. The high risk pool must eliminate waiting lists, cover individuals eligible for Medicare, limit premiums to 150% of average rates, conduct education initiatives, and provide preventive services for chronic diseases. Verification of citizenship or alien qualification is required. The pool must provide coverage for preventive services and disease management for chronic diseases. Only citizens and nationals of the United States are eligible to participate in a qualifying State high risk pool, with verification of citizenship or nationality required. The Secretary requires documentation of citizenship or nationality for participation in a qualifying State high risk pool. A pool must meet certain criteria to qualify under the Public Health Service Act. The Secretary has the authority to waive requirements for innovative programs. Additional funding is appropriated for the implementation of the Public Health Service Act. State reinsurance programs and qualifying State high risk pools are funded through appropriations under section 2745 of the Public Health Service Act. $15 billion is allocated for fiscal years 2015-2024, with an additional $10 billion for fiscal years 2020-2024. Definitions for health insurance coverage, health insurance issuer, and current section 2745 qualified high risk pool are provided in this section. The Secretary is defined as the Secretary of Health and Human Services. The term "qualified high risk pool" under section 2745(g) of the Public Health Service Act is defined in the Act. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Health and Human Services. The term "standard risk rate" is a rate determined by considering premium rates, using actuarial techniques, and reflecting anticipated claims and expenses. The term "State" refers to any of the 50 States or the District of Columbia.
